title: System Diagnostics

body.body: The ABS system has an on-board diagnostics feature which allows service technicians to retrieve stored data from the ECM using Triumph diagnostic software. Full details of the Triumph diagnostic software operation and how to interpret the results are given in the Triumph Diagnostic Tool User Guide.

The software is connected, via an interface cable, to the motorcycle using a dedicated diagnostic plug situated beneath the seat. By using a dedicated plug, no electrical connectors associated with the system are disturbed, reducing potential connector damage.

The software allows the user to retrieve data associated with the system sensors and actuators, test various component functions, read build data and make minor adjustments to the set-up of the system. The data and tests available are described on the following pages.
ABS System Diagnostics Tool Connection DR5 DS5
To connect the Triumph diagnostic interface to the motorcycle, remove the left hand side panel (see
) and release the diagnostic connector from its locating tang.
The diagnostic connector is red in colour and is connected to a blanking plug that is attached to the relay bracket.
The blanking plug is to prevent contamination.
Release the diagnostic connector from the relay tray.
Connect the diagnostic interface cable into the diagnostic connector
Connect the Triumph diagnostic interface into the diagnostic interface cable.
ABS System Diagnostic Interface DR5; DS5; D71; D74; DR4; DS1; DS4; DSA; DSB; DSX
When the diagnostic session is completed, disconnect the Triumph diagnostic interface.
Refit the diagnostic connector to its locating tang and refit the left hand side panel (see

body.body: Diagnostic trouble codes (DTCs) are logged in the ABS ECM memory when there is a confirmed fault in the system.
The codes are reported to the Triumph Diagnostic Tool as a four digit code.

search: System Diagnostics

The ABS system has an on-board diagnostics feature which allows service technicians to retrieve stored data from the ECM using Triumph diagnostic software. Full details of the Triumph diagnostic software operation and how to interpret the results are given in the Triumph Diagnostic Tool User Guide.

The software is connected, via an interface cable, to the motorcycle using a dedicated diagnostic plug situated beneath the seat. By using a dedicated plug, no electrical connectors associated with the system are disturbed, reducing potential connector damage.

The software allows the user to retrieve data associated with the system sensors and actuators, test various component functions, read build data and make minor adjustments to the set-up of the system. The data and tests available are described on the following pages.
Diagnostic Tool Connection
To connect the Triumph diagnostic interface to the motorcycle, remove the left hand side panel (see
Side Panels
) and release the diagnostic connector from its locating tang.
The diagnostic connector is red in colour and is connected to a blanking plug that is attached to the relay bracket.
The blanking plug is to prevent contamination.
You will need to use
service tool T3880538
with
service tool T3880057
to connect the diagnostic tool.
Release the diagnostic connector from the relay tray.
Diagnostic connector
Connect the diagnostic interface cable into the diagnostic connector
T3880538 - Diagnostic Interface Cable
Connect the Triumph diagnostic interface into the diagnostic interface cable.
T3880057 - Triumph Diagnostic Interface
When the diagnostic session is completed, disconnect the Triumph diagnostic interface.
Refit the diagnostic connector to its locating tang and refit the left hand side panel (see
Side Panels
Diagnostic Trouble Codes
Diagnostic trouble codes (DTCs) are logged in the ABS ECM memory when there is a confirmed fault in the system.
The codes are reported to the Triumph Diagnostic Tool as a four digit code.
